elements.content: To seek the effect that condition of the complexes has on the manufacture of the biaryl compounds, seven Ni­(II) complexes, namely, {[Ni­(L)0.5(bpa)­(H2O)]·2H2O} n (1), {[Ni2(L)­(dpp)2­(H2O)]·4H2O} n (2), {[Ni­(L)0.5(pbmb)­(H2O)]·H2O} n (3), {[Ni2(L)­(bmp)2­(H2O)]·7H2O} n (4), {[Ni­(L)0.5­(pbib)1.5]·2H2O} n (5), {[Ni2(L)­(pbib)1.5]·3H2O} n (6), and [Ni­(L)0.5­(beb)2­(H2O)] n (7) (bpa = 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethane, dpp = 1,3-di­(4-pyridyl)­propane, pbmb = 1,1′-(1,3-propane)­bis­(2-methylbenzimidazole), bmp = 1,5-bis­(2-methylbenzimidazol) pentane, pbib = 1,4-bis­(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)­benzene, beb = 1,4-bis­(2-ethylbenzimidazol-1-ylmethyl)­benzene), have been gained through hydro­(solvo)­thermal reactions of 5,5′-(hexane-1,6-diyl)-bis­(oxy)­diisophthalic acid ligand (H4L) with Ni­(II) metal ions under the regulation and control of six N-donor ligands. 3-fold interpenetrating complex 1 belongs to a (4,4)-connected 3D bbf net with a vertex symbol of (64·82)­(66) topology. 3-fold interpenetrating complex 2 presents a (4,4,4)-connected 3D bbf net with a Schläfli symbol of (66)2(64·82) topology. 3 features a (3,4)-connected 3,4L13 topology with a Schläfli symbol of (4·62)­(42·62·82) topology. 4 possesses a (4,4,4)-connected mog Moganite 3D network fabric, and the vertex symbol is (4·64·8)2­(42·62·82). 5 takes on a (4,5)-connected architecture, and the point symbol is (4·69)­(42·66·82). 6 is a (4,7)-connected framework, and the Schläfli symbol is (45·5)­(47·53·611). 7 has a (4,4)-connected 4,4L28 topology, and the point (Schläfli) symbol is (42·64)­(4·64·8). A systematic structural comparison of 1–7 signifies that their frameworks can be regulated through varied conformations of the flexible H4L ligand and diverse N-donor ligands. Between the proximal Ni­(II) ions, the variable-temperature (2–300 K) magnetic susceptibilities of 6 display overall weak antiferromagnetic coupling. In the complexes-catalyzed homocoupling reaction of iodobenzene, 3, 5, 6, and 7 have been verified to be effectual catalysts for the synthesis of the biaryl compounds.

elements.content: Seven Ni­(II) coordination complexes with fascinating architectures and topological motifs have been prepared. The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities of 6 display overall weak antiferromagnetic coupling between the adjacent Ni­(II) ions. In the complexes-catalyzed homocoupling reaction of iodobenzene, 3, 5, 6, and 7 can serve as effective catalysts for the synthesis of the biaryl motifs.

elements.content: The biaryl motif is a pivotal building block on account of its universal presence in plentiful biologically significant pharmaceuticals, natural products, materials, and agrochemicals. By means of its outstanding chemical and physical properties, the biaryl moiety can also be widely applied as a meritorious monomeric building block for conductive polymers, chiral recognition reagents for chromatography, and a core structure of liquid crystals. The development of effective preparation methods for the production of the biaryl has catched the growing attention of investigators. Homo- and cross-coupling reactions are the most frequently adopted techniques for the formation of carbon–carbon bonds, especially for producing biaryl structures and their heteroaromatic analogues. Speaking historically, the Ullmann reaction of aromatic halides was the first resultful method to prepare symmetrical biaryls when the metal copper served as catalysts. However, these reactions demand the expenditure of equimolar amounts of copper and severe reaction conditions (over 200 °C). To develop the milder reaction conditions, multifarious catalysts were introduced to the Ullmann reaction subsequently. In the palladium- or nickel-catalyzed homocoupling reaction, a reducing agent is indispensable, such as carbonic oxide gas, hydroquinone­(HQ), or hydrogen gas. Nevertheless, these kinds of metal catalysts accompanying with the reducing agents are not only expensive but also venenous. Moreover, the use of a Grignard reagent makes this reaction moisture-sensitive and not be controlled with ease in oxidative homocoupling reaction of aryl-metal reagents. Meanwhile, the use of the transition-metal halides also will make this reaction not green. Thus, new businesslike and eco-friendly catalysts for the homocoupling reaction are still required.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The biaryl motif is a pivotal building block on account of its universal presence in plentiful biologically significant pharmaceuticals, natural products, materials, and agrochemicals. By means of its outstanding chemical and physical properties, the biaryl moiety can also be widely applied as a meritorious monomeric building block for conductive polymers, chiral recognition reagents for chromatography, and a core structure of liquid crystals. The development of effective preparation methods for the production of the biaryl has catched the growing attention of investigators. Homo- and cross-coupling reactions are the most frequently adopted techniques for the formation of carbon-carbon bonds, especially for producing biaryl structures and their heteroaromatic analogues. Speaking historically, the Ullmann reaction of aromatic halides was the first resultful method to prepare symmetrical biaryls when the metal copper served as catalysts. However, these reactions demand the expenditure of equimolar amounts of copper and severe reaction conditions (over 200 °C). To develop the milder reaction conditions, multifarious catalysts were introduced to the Ullmann reaction subsequently. In the palladium- or nickel-catalyzed homocoupling reaction, a reducing agent is indispensable, such as carbonic oxide gas, hydroquinone(HQ), or hydrogen gas. Nevertheless, these kinds of metal catalysts accompanying with the reducing agents are not only expensive but also venenous. Moreover, the use of a Grignard reagent makes this reaction moisture-sensitive and not be controlled with ease in oxidative homocoupling reaction of aryl-metal reagents. Meanwhile, the use of the transition-metal halides also will make this reaction not green. Thus, new businesslike and eco-friendly catalysts for the homocoupling reaction are still required.

elements.content: In recent years, MOFs (metal−organic frameworks) have already appeared on the catalytic field by right of their advantages. Of the plentiful reasonable methods to the project of MOFs, the course of choosing well-designed organic ligands as building blocks has been demonstrated to be an effective strategy with metal ions/clusters as nodes. The coordination chemistry of the ether-linked flexible tetracarboxylic acids ligand 5,5′-(hexane-1,6-diyl)-bis­(oxy)­diisophthalic acid (H4L) has scarcely been inspected. The interaction between the flexibility and the rigidity of the organic constituent may have diverse connotations on the lattice shape. Thus, H4L is expected to be a puissant precursor in the creation of miscellaneous high-dimensional structures/topologies. First, the ligand H4L can be deprotonated to the homologous carboxylate species (H3L–, H2L2–, H1L3–, and L4–), admitting its various coordination fashions to the inorganic connectors. Second, the (−CH2−)6 spacers with the flexible nature between the two oxyisophthalic acid fragments will render the carboxyl groups to link to metal ions in disparate directions, furnishing more likelihood for the architecture of skeletons with versatile topologies and functional properties. Third, the existence of two methoxy groups will also enhance the flexibility of the (−CH2−)6 long chain. Forth, the cooperation of four rotating carboxyl groups and eight freely twisting atoms would afford a directional control at three-dimensional (3D) extensions. On the other hand, the fully deprotonated modalities of the H4L ligand present more negative charge (−4 valence). It is a good approach to adopt neutral N-heterocyclic spacers as secondary coligands to pillar the tetracarboxylate–metal networks and forward structural diversity in establishing multidimensional MOFs.

elements.content: Enlightened by the foregoing discussion, by drawing a series of N-donor coligands (Scheme S1) into the Ni­(II)/L4– synthesis system, seven Ni­(II) coordination complexes, possessing more complicated structures and intriguing topologies, formulated as {[Ni­(L)0.5­(bpa)­(H2O)]·2H2O} n (1), {[Ni2(L)­(dpp)2­(H2O)]·4H2O} n (2), {[Ni­(L)0.5(pbmb)­(H2O)]·H2O} n (3), {[Ni2(L)­(bmp)2­(H2O)]·7H2O} n (4), {[Ni­(L)0.5­(pbib)1.5]·2H2O} n (5), {[Ni2(L)­(pbib)1.5]·3H2O} n (6), and [Ni­(L)0.5­(beb)2­(H2O)] n (7), have been achieved to conduct the experiments on the preparation of the biaryl compounds. The structures and topological analyses of 1–7, in conjunction with a systemic research about the influence of different N-donor coligands on the ultima skeletons, will be stated. The thermal stabilities, solvent resistance property, and photophysical properties of 1–7 have been inquiried in detail. Moreover, the magnetic susceptibility measurement of 6 has also been performed.

elements.content: All of the solvents and reagents were commercially practicable. H4L was synthesized in accordance with a revised procedure from the reported literature. Ligands pbmb, bmp, pbib, and beb were manufactured according to the literature. A Bruker-ALPHA spectrophotometer, which employs KBr pellets, is adopted to record the FT-IR spectra of complexes within the 400–4000 cm–1 scale. Thermogravimetric analyses were implemented using a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer with a heating speed of 10 °C min–1 in the air stream. A FLASH EA 1112 analyzer was selected and used for performing the elemental analyses of complexes. XRD patterns of complexes were accomplished on a PANalytical X’Pert PRO diffractometer making use of Cu Kα1 radiation. Diffuse reflectivity spectra of the solid samples were gathered by virtue of a Cary 500 spectrophotometer, which is equipped with a 110 nm diameter integrating sphere. The whole testing is from 200 to 800 nm utilizing barium sulfate as a standard.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

All of the solvents and reagents were commercially practicable. H4L was synthesized in accordance with a revised procedure from the reported literature. Ligands pbmb, bmp, pbib, and beb were manufactured according to the literature. A Bruker-ALPHA spectrophotometer, which employs KBr pellets, is adopted to record the FT-IR spectra of complexes within the 400-4000 cm-1 scale. Thermogravimetric analyses were implemented using a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer with a heating speed of 10 °C min-1 in the air stream. A FLASH EA 1112 analyzer was selected and used for performing the elemental analyses of complexes. XRD patterns of complexes were accomplished on a PANalytical X'Pert PRO diffractometer making use of Cu Kα1 radiation. Diffuse reflectivity spectra of the solid samples were gathered by virtue of a Cary 500 spectrophotometer, which is equipped with a 110 nm diameter integrating sphere. The whole testing is from 200 to 800 nm utilizing barium sulfate as a standard.

elements.content: A 0.2 mmol quantity of Ni­(OAc)2·4H2O (0.0496 g), 0.1 mmol of L (0.0446 g), 0.1 mmol of bpa (0.0184 g), and 0.4 mmol of NaOH (0.0160 g) were weighed into a 25 mL container; then, 8 mL of distilled H2O was poured into the mixture. elements.content: The collections of crystallographic data of the 1–7 were fulfilled at indoor temperature using a Rigaku Saturn 724 CCD diffractomer, which was equipped with Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Utilizing a multiscan program, absorption corrections of these data were enforced. In the light of Lorentz and polarization effects, these data were corrected. The structures of 1–7 were handled by firsthand methods, and then refined by means of F 2 with a full-matrix least-squares technique. All the non-hydrogen atoms were anisotropically refined. The hydrogen atoms of H4L, which were assigned at perfect positions, were isotropically refined. For complexes 1–7 and complex 6 under specific conditions, the results of their X-ray analyses are summed up in Table S1 (in the Supporting Information). Bond lengths and bond angles under selection of 1–7 and 6 under specific conditions are included in Table S2. For 1–7: CCDC reference numbers 1052514–1052520. For 6-H2O: CCDC reference number 1052521.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Data Collection and Refinement

The collections of crystallographic data of the 1-7 were fulfilled at indoor temperature using a Rigaku Saturn 724 CCD diffractomer, which was equipped with Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Utilizing a multiscan program, absorption corrections of these data were enforced. In the light of Lorentz and polarization effects, these data were corrected. The structures of 1-7 were handled by firsthand methods, and then refined by means of F 2 with a full-matrix least-squares technique. All the non-hydrogen atoms were anisotropically refined. The hydrogen atoms of H4L, which were assigned at perfect positions, were isotropically refined. For complexes 1-7 and complex 6 under specific conditions, the results of their X-ray analyses are summed up in Table S1 (in the Supporting Information). Bond lengths and bond angles under selection of 1-7 and 6 under specific conditions are included in Table S2. For 1-7: CCDC reference numbers 1052514-1052520. For 6-H2O: CCDC reference number 1052521.

Solvent Resistance Experiment

The experiment was researched by suspending the samples in boiling frequently used solvents for 48 h. In this process, the samples were supervised under a optical microscope. elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Experiment

Under the applied field of 1 kOe, the magnetic susceptibilities (χ M  T - T and χ M  -1 - T) were carried out on a SQUID MPMS XL-7 instrument in the temperature region of 2-300 K. With the help of Pascal's constants, we also executed the diamagnetic corrections for the magnetic data of 6.

elements.content: Iodobenzene (0.5 mmol), catalyst (0.05 mmol, complexes 1–7), and magnesium ribbon (0.6 mmol) were mixed together and refluxed in anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (2 mL) under dry air. After 6 h, the cool reacting solution was filtrated and the dilute hydrochloric acid (0.5 N, 10 mL) was added into the filtrate. The mixture was then extracted with acetic ether, and the combined organic layers were washed with water and then dried by anhydrous sodium sulfate, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The raw product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel with hexane. Column chromatography was implemented with 200–300 mesh silica gel. 1H NMR spectra were taken on a 400 MHz instrument (see the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
General Procedure of the Preparation of the Biaryl Compounds with Catalysts 1-7  

Iodobenzene (0.5 mmol), catalyst (0.05 mmol, complexes 1-7), and magnesium ribbon (0.6 mmol) were mixed together and refluxed in anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (2 mL) under dry air. After 6 h, the cool reacting solution was filtrated and the dilute hydrochloric acid (0.5 N, 10 mL) was added into the filtrate. The mixture was then extracted with acetic ether, and the combined organic layers were washed with water and then dried by anhydrous sodium sulfate, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The raw product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel with hexane. Column chromatography was implemented with 200-300 mesh silica gel. 1H NMR spectra were taken on a 400 MHz instrument (see the Supporting Information).

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 1 comprises one crystallographically independent Ni­(II) ion, one bpa ligand, half a L anion, and one coordinated water molecule as well as two lattice water molecules (Figure S1a). The Ni1 ion is six coordinated with an octahedral coordination geometry, which is fulfilled by two oxygen atoms (O1 and O2) originating from one μ1-η1:η1-chelate carboxylate, one oxygen atom (O5A) supplied by one monodentate carboxylate, and one nitrogen atom (N1) of the bpa ligand forming the equatorial plane, and one oxygen atom (O3) of a coordinated water molecule as well as one nitrogen atom (N2B) of the bpa ligand that is situated in the axial positions with an O3–Ni1–N2B bond angle of 172.80(1) °. The Ni–O bond distances vary from 2.047(3) to 2.255(3) Å, while the Ni1–N1/N2B bond lengths are 2.052(3)/2.081(3) Å, severally.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of {[Ni(L)0.5(bpa)(H2O)]⋅2H2O} n  (1)

The asymmetric unit of 1 comprises one crystallographically independent Ni(II) ion, one bpa ligand, half a L anion, and one coordinated water molecule as well as two lattice water molecules (Figure S1a). The Ni1 ion is six coordinated with an octahedral coordination geometry, which is fulfilled by two oxygen atoms (O1 and O2) originating from one μ1-η1:η1-chelate carboxylate, one oxygen atom (O5A) supplied by one monodentate carboxylate, and one nitrogen atom (N1) of the bpa ligand forming the equatorial plane, and one oxygen atom (O3) of a coordinated water molecule as well as one nitrogen atom (N2B) of the bpa ligand that is situated in the axial positions with an O3-Ni1-N2B bond angle of 172.80(1) °. The Ni-O bond distances vary from 2.047(3) to 2.255(3) Å, while the Ni1-N1/N2B bond lengths are 2.052(3)/2.081(3) Å, severally.

elements.content: There exist five torsion angles of 168.5(1), −147.6(1), −60.5(2), −51.6(2), and −58.9(2) ° along the C chain and ether bond in the H4L. The completely deprotonated H4L in 1 exhibits one coordination mode: (κ1)-(κ2)-(κ1)-(κ2)-μ4 (Mode I), as shown in Scheme S2. In this mode, two carboxylate groups take chelating bidentate coordination modes, and the other two carboxylate groups show the monodentate fashions. On the basis of the connection mode, each Ni­(II) ion is joined by L4– anions into a 2D net with left- and right-handed helical chains, which are arranged alternately running along the bc plane (a). Both of them have a pitch of 17.606(4) Å, which is in perfect accordance with the length of the b axis. The 1D infinite zigzag chain (Ni­(II)/bpa chain) along the crystallographic c axis is produced by the anti-conformational bpa spacers with a C–C–C–C torsion angle of 179.39° and Ni­(II) ions carrying a Ni···Ni distance of 13.3391 Å (Figure S1b). The Ni­(II)/L4– nets are pillared by 1D chains of Ni­(II)/bpa via the Ni–N connections to produce a 3D framework with large channels (16.49 Å × 18.63 Å) along the c axis (b). To stabilize the overall framework and minimize the big hollow cavities in 1, the large chamber facilitates other two independent equivalent networks to interpenetrate, triggering the creation of a 3-fold interpenetrated skeleton (c).

elements.content: Topologically, the Ni1 cation can be clarified as a 4-connected node, which is connected to four equivalent nodes by means of two bpa ligands and two L4– anions. Each L4– anion links with four Ni­(II) atoms, so the L4– can be identified as a 4-connected node. Moreover, the bpa is simplified as linear linkers. Accordingly, the whole structure of 1 is related to a (4,4)-connected bbf net with a vertex symbol of (64·82)­(66) (c).

elements.content: The two unique nickel cations including Ni1 and Ni2 (entire site occupancy, severally) are all situated in distorted octahedral coordination geometries (Figure S2a). The Ni1 ion is ligated by O1, O2, O3B, O4B atoms from two distinct μ1-η1:η1-chelate carboxylates (Ni1–O distances: 2.002(1)–2.281(2) Å) and N1, N2A atoms from two separate dpp ligands (Ni1–N1 = 2.034(2) Å, Ni1–N2A = 2.027(2) Å). The O2, O3B, O4B, and N2A atoms comprise the equatorial plane, and the O1 and N1 atoms occupy axial positions. The bond angles around Ni1 range from 61.11(5)° to 159.92(5)°. The Ni2 ion is equatorially surrounded by O7, O8 atoms from one μ1-η1:η1-chelate carboxylate (Ni2–O7 = 2.097(2) Å, Ni2–O8 = 2.152(2) Å), one oxygen (O9C) from one monodentate carboxylate (Ni2–O9C = 2.049(1) Å), and the N3 atom from the dpp ligand (Ni2–N3 = 2.056(2) Å). The two axial sites on the metal are occupied by one N atom (N4D) from one dpp ligand (Ni2–N4D = 2.085(2) Å) and one terminal water oxygen atom (O11) (Ni2–O11 = 2.128(2) Å). The bond angles around Ni2 range from 61.52(6)° to 179.29(7) °.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of {[Ni2(L)(dpp)2(H2O)]⋅4H2O} n  (2)

The two unique nickel cations including Ni1 and Ni2 (entire site occupancy, severally) are all situated in distorted octahedral coordination geometries (Figure S2a). The Ni1 ion is ligated by O1, O2, O3B, O4B atoms from two distinct μ1-η1:η1-chelate carboxylates (Ni1-O distances: 2.002(1)-2.281(2) Å) and N1, N2A atoms from two separate dpp ligands (Ni1-N1 = 2.034(2) Å, Ni1-N2A = 2.027(2) Å). The O2, O3B, O4B, and N2A atoms comprise the equatorial plane, and the O1 and N1 atoms occupy axial positions. The bond angles around Ni1 range from 61.11(5)° to 159.92(5)°. The Ni2 ion is equatorially surrounded by O7, O8 atoms from one μ1-η1:η1-chelate carboxylate (Ni2-O7 = 2.097(2) Å, Ni2-O8 = 2.152(2) Å), one oxygen (O9C) from one monodentate carboxylate (Ni2-O9C = 2.049(1) Å), and the N3 atom from the dpp ligand (Ni2-N3 = 2.056(2) Å). The two axial sites on the metal are occupied by one N atom (N4D) from one dpp ligand (Ni2-N4D = 2.085(2) Å) and one terminal water oxygen atom (O11) (Ni2-O11 = 2.128(2) Å). The bond angles around Ni2 range from 61.52(6)° to 179.29(7) °.

elements.content: Two different kinds of dpp ligands (namely, dpp-I and dpp-II) exist in 2; both of them exhibit a TT (T = trans) conformation in the case of the counter orientations of the −CH2– groups. The dpp-I coordinates to Ni1­(II) centers to generate a 1D left-handed helical chain with a pitch of 16.951(3) Å, while Ni2­(II) centers are joined by dpp-II to engender a 1D right-handed helical chain that possesses the same pitch (a). Passing its four carboxylate groups, each L4– acts as a μ4-bridge to connect four Ni­(II) ions and the coordination mode of (κ2)-(κ1)-(κ2)-(κ2)-μ4 (Mode II of Scheme S2) for L4– is found in complex 2. The linkage of L4– anions and Ni­(II) cations provides a 2D Ni-L backbone along the bc plane (b). Because of the flexibility of L ligands, there exists left- and right-handed helical chains in the 2D Ni-L backbone of 2. Their screw axes are also all parallel with the b axis; in addition, the pitch is also 16.951(3) Å. These 2D Ni-L networks are connected together by sharing the Ni­(II) atoms with 1D Ni­(II)-dpp chains to furnish a 3D metal–organic framework containing the cavities (c). Three such nets are interwoven into a 3-fold interpenetrated 3D structure (d).

Crystal Structure of {[Ni(L)0.5(pbmb)(H2O)]⋅H2O} n  (3)

Delineated in Figure S3a, the Ni center is bonded to three oxygen atoms belonging to two separated L4- ligands, one oxygen atom (O6) from one coordinated water molecule, as well as a N1 atom and N3 atom from two pbmb ligands, to generate a distorted octahedral coordination geometry. elements.content: In 3, the pbmb adopts an asymmetrical trans-conformation with two disparate Ndonor···N–Csp3···Csp3 torsion angles of 89.204° and 103.643°. Ni1 and symmetry-related Ni1B (1 – x, 2 – y, 1 – z) are concatenated by two pbmb ligands forming a [Ni­(pbmb)]2 unit with a 16-membered metalloring (a). The bridged Ni···Ni distance along μ-pbmb is 9.932 Å. The L4– anions connect four Ni­(II) cations in a (κ2)-(κ1)-(κ2)-(κ1)-μ4 coordination mode (Mode III of Scheme S2). In this mode, four carboxylic groups behave as μ1-η1:η1, μ1-η1:η0, μ1-η1:η1, and μ1-η1:η0 modes in a clockwise direction, separately. On account of this coordination mode, the L4– anion works as a bridging ligand to bind the Ni­(II) ions, building 1D ladder chains along the c direction (b). The Ni­(II) ions of two contiguous 1D Ni­(II)/L4– chains were connected by the trans-conformational pbmb, effecting the 2D sheet of 3 parallel to the ac crystal face (c).

elements.content: As illustrated in Figure S4a, the Ni1 ion is located in an octahedral coordination environment, which is anchored by one oxygen (O1) from one monodentate carboxylate (Ni1–O1 = 2.114(2) Å), two oxygens (O3, O4) from one μ1-η1:η1-chelate carboxylate (Ni1–O3 = 2.114(2) Å, Ni1–O4 = 2.121(3) Å), one O5 atom of a coordinated water molecule (Ni1–O5 = 2.068(2) Å), and N1, N5 atoms from two bmp ligands (Ni1–N1 = 2.056(3) Å, Ni1–N5 = 2.136(3) Å). The axial positions are padded with O1 and N5 with an O1–Ni1–N5 bond angle of 172.59(1)°. Ni2 also takes on a distorted octahedral coordination geometry, nevertheless, which is coordinated by four carboxylic oxygen atoms (O6C, O7C, O8, and O9) from two unlike L ligands (Ni2–O6C = 2.061(2) Å, Ni2–O7C = 2.243(2) Å, Ni2–O8 = 2.104(2) Å, Ni2–O9 = 2.144(2) Å) and two nitrogen atoms (N4A, N8B) from two bmp ligands (Ni2–N4A = 2.044(3) Å, Ni2–N8B = 2.048(3) Å). The bond angles around Ni2 ions fall in the range of 60.87(9)–168.96(9)°.

Crystal Structure of {[Ni2(L)(bmp)2(H2O)]⋅7H2O} n  (4)

As illustrated in Figure S4a, the Ni1 ion is located in an octahedral coordination environment, which is anchored by one oxygen (O1) from one monodentate carboxylate (Ni1-O1 = 2.114(2) Å), two oxygens (O3, O4) from one μ1-η1:η1-chelate carboxylate (Ni1-O3 = 2.114(2) Å, Ni1-O4 = 2.121(3) Å), one O5 atom of a coordinated water molecule (Ni1-O5 = 2.068(2) Å), and N1, N5 atoms from two bmp ligands (Ni1-N1 = 2.056(3) Å, Ni1-N5 = 2.136(3) Å). The axial positions are padded with O1 and N5 with an O1-Ni1-N5 bond angle of 172.59(1)°. Ni2 also takes on a distorted octahedral coordination geometry, nevertheless, which is coordinated by four carboxylic oxygen atoms (O6C, O7C, O8, and O9) from two unlike L ligands (Ni2-O6C = 2.061(2) Å, Ni2-O7C = 2.243(2) Å, Ni2-O8 = 2.104(2) Å, Ni2-O9 = 2.144(2) Å) and two nitrogen atoms (N4A, N8B) from two bmp ligands (Ni2-N4A = 2.044(3) Å, Ni2-N8B = 2.048(3) Å). The bond angles around Ni2 ions fall in the range of 60.87(9)-168.96(9)°.

elements.content: There are two independent bmp ligands in 4. The first type (bmp-I) adopts an asymmetric cis-conformation, and two diverse Ndonor···N–Csp3···Csp3 torsion angles are 95.176° and 115.858°, singly. The second type (bmp-II) adopts an asymmetric trans-conformation, and two distinct Ndonor···N–Csp3···Csp3 torsion angles are 73.812° and 86.517°, severally. Ni1­(II) and Ni2­(II) atoms are alternately joined by the two bmp to give a 36-membered macrocyclic ring with a Ni1···Ni2 separation of 11.441(3) Å across the bridging bmp-I and 12.030(4) Å across the bridging bmp-II, singly (a). The L ligand possesses one coordination mode (Mode IV of Scheme S2): (κ2)-(κ2)-(κ1)-(κ2)-μ4 to coordinate with four Ni2+ cations through four carboxyl oxygen atoms. The three carboxyl groups of them all adopt chelating bidentate coordination modes, the forth one in a monodentate coordination pattern. The Ni­(II) atoms are concatenated by L4– anions to yield a 1D parallelogram channel with the dimensions of approximately 9.2 × 10.4 Å2 (including van der Waals radii of the atoms) (b). The expansion of 4 into a 3D net is also implemented by linking 36-membered metallorings through 1D parallelogram channels (c).

elements.content: After topology analysis of 4 is executed, we can consider each L4– anion as a 4-connecting node, which is jointed to four isovalent nodes through two Ni1 cations and two Ni2 cations. The Ni1 and Ni2 cations can be also considered as 4-connected nodes, severally, which are connected to four equivalent nodes through two L4– anions and two bmp ligands, singly. Moreover, the bmp-I and bmp-II are reduced to linear linkers, separately. Eventually, the entire structure of 4 can be supposed to be a (4,4,4)-connected mog Moganite net, and the vertex symbol is (4·64·8)2­(42·62·82) (d).

elements.content: As illustrated in Figure S5a, the Ni­(II) atom sits in a twisty octahedral coordination geometry with a NiO2N3 coordination environment, which is defined by N1, N3, and N5 atoms from three pbib ligands and O1, O2, and O3A atoms from two different L4– ligands. The variation range of Ni–O bond separations is from 2.048(2) to 2.266(2) Å, while that of Ni–N bond lengths is from 2.063(2) to 2.105(2) Å.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of {[Ni(L)0.5(pbib)1.5]⋅2H2O} n  (5)

As illustrated in Figure S5a, the Ni(II) atom sits in a twisty octahedral coordination geometry with a NiO2N3 coordination environment, which is defined by N1, N3, and N5 atoms from three pbib ligands and O1, O2, and O3A atoms from two different L4- ligands. The variation range of Ni-O bond separations is from 2.048(2) to 2.266(2) Å, while that of Ni-N bond lengths is from 2.063(2) to 2.105(2) Å.

elements.content: There are three classes of standalone pbib, and all of them present a symmetrical trans-conformation. Ndonor···N–Csp3···Csp3 torsion angles of pbib-I, pbib-II, and pbib-III are 50.921, 68.585, and 81.220°, separately. The three types of pbib behave as a bidentate mode to connect with two proximal Ni­(II) ions alternately to provide a 2D net along the a axis (a). The Ni···Ni distances across the pbib-I, pbib-II, and pbib-III bridges are 13.384 Å (pbib-I), 13.785 Å (pbib-II), and 14.083 Å (pbib-III), separately. The L ligand in 5 takes on one coordination mode (Mode V of Scheme S2: (κ1)-(κ2)-(κ1)-(κ2)-μ4) to coordinate with Ni2+ cations via six carboxyl oxygens, and four carboxyl groups of them adopt μ1-η1:η0, μ2-η1:η1, μ1-η1:η0, and μ2-η1:η1 coordination modes, severally. The neighboring Ni­(II) atoms are jointed by the L ligand, leading to the formation of a 1D ladder chain along the a direction (b). The Ni/pbib 2D layers and the Ni/L4– 1D chain are held together by sharing the Ni­(II) atoms, resulting in a 3D architecture (c).

elements.content: Topologically, each Ni­(II) ion is encircled by three pbib ligands and two L4– ligands, and each L4– is linked with three Ni­(II) ions. If the Ni­(II) ion is perceived as a 5-connector, the L4– can be considered as 4-connected nodes and pbib is taken for linkers. The 3D skelecton of 5 can be classified as a (4,5)-connected new topology, and the point symbol is (4·69)­(42·66·82) (d).

elements.content: 6 presents an elegant (4,7)-connected 3D network. Figure S6a illustrates the coordination surroundings of the Ni­(II) ions. The Ni1­(II) ion and Ni2­(II) ion both adopt distorted octahedral coordination environments in nature. The Ni1­(II) ion is bound with O1, O4, O5B, O6B, and O9A, which derives from four L4– anions as well as one nitrogen atom (N1) coming from one separate pbib. The Ni1–O bond separations vary from 2.015(3) to 2.145(2) Å, while the Ni1–N1 bond length is 2.060(3) Å. Different from Ni1, the Ni2­(II) ion is surrounded by four carboxyl oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3, and O8A) originating from three L4– anions and N3, N5 atoms from two pbib. The length range of Ni2–O bonds is from 2.028(3) to 2.288(2) Å; nevertheless, the lengths of Ni2–N3 and Ni2–N5 bonds are 2.104(3) and 2.052(3) Å, separately.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of {[Ni2(L)(pbib)1.5]⋅3H2O} n  (6)

 6 presents an elegant (4,7)-connected 3D network. Figure S6a illustrates the coordination surroundings of the Ni(II) ions. The Ni1(II) ion and Ni2(II) ion both adopt distorted octahedral coordination environments in nature. The Ni1(II) ion is bound with O1, O4, O5B, O6B, and O9A, which derives from four L4- anions as well as one nitrogen atom (N1) coming from one separate pbib. The Ni1-O bond separations vary from 2.015(3) to 2.145(2) Å, while the Ni1-N1 bond length is 2.060(3) Å. Different from Ni1, the Ni2(II) ion is surrounded by four carboxyl oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3, and O8A) originating from three L4- anions and N3, N5 atoms from two pbib. The length range of Ni2-O bonds is from 2.028(3) to 2.288(2) Å; nevertheless, the lengths of Ni2-N3 and Ni2-N5 bonds are 2.104(3) and 2.052(3) Å, separately.

elements.content: In this structure, the L4– ligand acts as a seven-connector to link seven Ni atoms with the (κ1-κ1)-(κ2-κ1-μ2)-(κ1-κ1)-(κ2)-μ7 coordination mode (Mode VI of Scheme S2), in which four carboxyl groups adopt syn–anti-μ2-η1:η1, μ2-η2:η1, syn–anti-μ2-η1:η1, and μ1-η1:η1 coordination modes, severally. Ni1 and Ni2 ions are joined together through two μ2-η2:η1 bridging carboxylate groups and one μ2-η2:η1 bridging carboxylate group to furnish a binuclear [Ni2(CO2)3] SBU. The intermetallic distance of Ni1···Ni2 is about 3.440 Å within the subunit. The binuclear [Ni2(CO2)3] units are expanded by the L4– ligands to form a 2D layer containing 1D channels with the dimensions of roughly 8.7 × 9.9 Å2 (a).

elements.content: Similar to 5, there are also three kinds of freestanding pbib, all of which also show a symmetrical trans-conformation, while Ndonor···N–Csp3···Csp3 torsion angles of pbib-I, pbib-II, and pbib-III are 56.823, 119.089, and 138.234°, singly. The two adjoining Ni2­(II) ions are bridged by pbib-I and pbib-III to induce a 1D meso-helix chain (b). The helical pitch is 10.063(2) Å, which is related to the length of the b axis. Moreover, the Ni2···Ni2 separations across the pbib bridges are 12.576 Å (pbib-I) and 15.461 Å (pbib-III), separately. Meantime, the pbib-II links the Ni1­(II) ions with a Ni1···Ni1 separation of 14.883 Å crossing in the middle of the above 1D channels. The complicated 3D framework of 6 was constructed through the combination of the 1D meso-helix chains Ni2­(II)-(pbib-I)-(pbib-III) and the Ni­(II)-L4– 2D nets (c).

elements.content: On the basis of the concept of topology, the binuclear SBU can be deemed to be a seven-connected node, linking with three pbib ligands and four L4– anions. The L4– ligand links four binuclear SBUs. Thus, the L4– ligand is considered as a 4-connected node. The final 3D skeleton exhibits a binodal (4,7)-connected new topology, and the Schläfli symbol is (45·5)­(47·53·611) (d).

 7 is a 2D bilayer network. As demonstrated in Figure S7a, the octahedral coordination around Ni1 is supplied by three carboxylate oxygens (O1, O2, and O5A) from two different L4- moieties (Ni1-O1 = 2.151(2) Å; Ni1-O2 = 2.104(2) Å; Ni1-O5A = 2.067(2) Å) and an O3 atom from coordinated water Ni1-O3 = 2.068(2) Å) generating the square base, and the axial coordination is endowed by N1 and N3 atoms from two beb ligands (Ni1-N1 = 2.101(3) Å; Ni1-N3 = 2.125(3) Å).

elements.content: The L4– anions connect four Ni­(II) cations, where two carboxylate groups take μ1-η1:η1 coordination modes, and the other two carboxylate groups adopt μ1-η1:η0 fashions (Mode VII of Scheme S2). In this way, the Ni­(II) atoms are jointed by the L4– anions to generate a 1D ladder-like chain propagating along the ab plane (a). There is one independent beb ligand in 7. The beb adopts an asymmetric trans-conformation, and two disparate Ndonor···N–Csp3···Csp3 torsion angles are 80.554° and 109.185°, severally. The Ni1­(II) ions are bridged by this type of beb to produce a 1D zigzag chain stretchting along the c axis (Ni···Ni distance: 14.241 Å) (b). The Ni­(II)/L4– 1D ladder-like chain and 1D Ni­(II)/beb chain connect each other through sharing the common Ni­(II) ions to result in the formation of a 2D bilayer net (c).

Thus, the resulting structure of 7 is accounted as a (4,4)-connected net with its point (Schläfli) symbol of (42·64)­(4·64·8), which is fingered as 4,4L28 topology (d).

elements.content: On the strength of the upper structure descriptions, we find that the L4– anion can adopt various coordination modes, linking to four (complexes 1–5, 7) or seven (complex 6) metal ions. In 1–5 and 7, each L4– anion all connects four Ni­(II) ions corresponding to Modes I–V and VII, severally (Scheme S2). Different from 1–5 and 7, each L4– anion in 6 links with seven Ni­(II) ions corresponding to Mode VI (Scheme S2). The structural diversities of 1–7 can be vested in the divergent coordination modes of carboxylate groups and the discrimination of distortion degree of the flexible chain in the H4L molecule.
elements.clean_text:
Effects of the Coordination Modes of the L4- Anion on Complexes 1-7 

On the strength of the upper structure descriptions, we find that the L4- anion can adopt various coordination modes, linking to four (complexes 1-5, 7) or seven (complex 6) metal ions. In 1-5 and 7, each L4- anion all connects four Ni(II) ions corresponding to Modes I-V and VII, severally (Scheme S2). Different from 1-5 and 7, each L4- anion in 6 links with seven Ni(II) ions corresponding to Mode VI (Scheme S2). The structural diversities of 1-7 can be vested in the divergent coordination modes of carboxylate groups and the discrimination of distortion degree of the flexible chain in the H4L molecule.

elements.content: For 1, 3, 5, and 7, the carboxylate groups of L4– all bind with the central metals via a (κ1)-(κ2)-(κ1)-(κ2)-μ4 fashion. Different from each other, this kind of coordination fashion in 1 causes the appearance of a 2D Ni-L4– net with helical chains; that in 3 brings about the generation of a 1D Ni-L4– ladder chain with a 19.494 Å Ni···Ni distance across 38-membered rings comprising two L4– and two Ni­(II) ions; that in 5 affords a 1D Ni-L4– ladder chain with a 14.492 Å Ni···Ni distance across 38-membered rings comprising two L4– and two Ni­(II) ions; and that in 7 induces the appearance of a 1D Ni-L4– ladder chain with a 13.632 Å Ni···Ni distance across 38-membered rings making up two L4– and two Ni­(II) ions. For 2 and 4, the carboxylate groups of L4– both coordinate with the central metals via a (κ2)-(κ2)-(κ1)-(κ2)-μ4 fashion. This type of coordination fashion in 2 gives rise to the presence of a 2D Ni-L backbone accompanying with helical chains, while that in 4 results in a 1D parallelogram channel. For 6, the carboxylate group of the L4– anion links with seven Ni­(II) ions through the (κ1-κ1)-(κ2-κ1-μ2)-(κ1-κ1)-(κ2)-μ7 coordination mode, forming a 2D layer containing 1D channels.

Different from each other, this kind of coordination fashion in 1 causes the appearance of a 2D Ni-L4- net with helical chains; that in 3 brings about the generation of a 1D Ni-L4- ladder chain with a 19.494 Å Ni⋅⋅⋅Ni distance across 38-membered rings comprising two L4- and two Ni(II) ions; that in 5 affords a 1D Ni-L4- ladder chain with a 14.492 Å Ni⋅⋅⋅Ni distance across 38-membered rings comprising two L4- and two Ni(II) ions; and that in 7 induces the appearance of a 1D Ni-L4- ladder chain with a 13.632 Å Ni⋅⋅⋅Ni distance across 38-membered rings making up two L4- and two Ni(II) ions. For 2 and 4, the carboxylate groups of L4- both coordinate with the central metals via a (κ2)-(κ2)-(κ1)-(κ2)-μ4 fashion. This type of coordination fashion in 2 gives rise to the presence of a 2D Ni-L backbone accompanying with helical chains, while that in 4 results in a 1D parallelogram channel. For 6, the carboxylate group of the L4- anion links with seven Ni(II) ions through the (κ1-κ1)-(κ2-κ1-μ2)-(κ1-κ1)-(κ2)-μ7 coordination mode, forming a 2D layer containing 1D channels.

elements.content: The N-donors wield a profound influence on the eventual structures of the complexes. The anti-conformational bpa spacers in 1 bridge Ni­(II) ions to produce a 1D infinite zigzag chain. The Ni­(II)/bpa chain serves as pillars, linking the neighboring Ni­(II)/L4– nets into a 3-fold interpenetrated 3D framework with a vertex symbol of (64·82)­(66). For 2, two different kinds of dpp ligands I and II act as bidentate ligands coordinating to Ni (II) ions, singly. The dpp-I bridges Ni1­(II) centers to offer a 1D left-handed helical chain, while dpp-II bridges Ni2­(II) centers to furnish a 1D right-handed helical chain. The 2D Ni-L networks in 2 are tied together by sharing the Ni­(II) centers with 1D Ni­(II)-dpp chains to yield a 3-fold interpenetrated 3D skeleton, and the Schläfli symbol is (66)2(64·82). The pbmb adopting an asymmetrical trans-conformation in 3 links a Ni1 atom as well as a symmetry-related Ni1B (1 – x, 2 – y, 1 – z) atom, affording a [Ni­(pbmb)]2 unit following a 16-membered metalloring. The Ni­(II) ions of two adjoining 1D Ni­(II)/L4– chains were connected together by the trans-conformational pbmb supplying a 2D sheet with a point symbol of (4·62)­(42·62·82). For 4, Ni1­(II) and Ni2­(II) atoms are alternately bridged by the two classes of bmp (bmp-I and bmp-II) to lead to 36-membered macrocyclic rings, which combine with 1D Ni-L parallelogram channels to result in a 3D network with a vertex symbol of (4·64·8)2­(42·62·82). For 5, the three types of pbib (pbib-I, pbib-II, and pbib-III) behave as a bidentate mode to joint two contiguous Ni­(II) ions alternately to afford a 2D net. The Ni/pbib 2D layers are connected by a Ni/L4– 1D chain, inducing a 3D architecture with a point symbol of (4·69)­(42·66·82). In 6, there are also three kinds of independent pbib (pbib-I, pbib-II, and pbib-III). The two adjoining Ni2­(II) ions are bridged by pbib-I and pbib-III to produce a 1D meso-helix chain. At the same time, the pbib-II links the Ni1­(II) ions crossing in the middle of 1D channels that are included in the Ni-L 2D layer. The combination of the 1D meso-helix chains Ni2­(II)-(pbib-I)-(pbib-III) and the Ni­(II)-L4– 2D nets constructs a complicated 3D framework with the Schläfli symbol of (45·5)­(47·53·611). In 7, a trans-conformational beb ligand coordinates with Ni1­(II) atoms into a 1D chain. The combination of the 1D Ni­(II)/beb chain and 1D Ni­(II)/L4– chain leads to a 2D bilayer net.
elements.clean_text:
Effects of the N-Donor Ligands on the Frameworks of Complexes 1-7 

The N-donors wield a profound influence on the eventual structures of the complexes. The anti-conformational bpa spacers in 1 bridge Ni(II) ions to produce a 1D infinite zigzag chain. The Ni(II)/bpa chain serves as pillars, linking the neighboring Ni(II)/L4- nets into a 3-fold interpenetrated 3D framework with a vertex symbol of (64⋅82)(66). For 2, two different kinds of dpp ligands I and II act as bidentate ligands coordinating to Ni (II) ions, singly. The dpp-I bridges Ni1(II) centers to offer a 1D left-handed helical chain, while dpp-II bridges Ni2(II) centers to furnish a 1D right-handed helical chain. The 2D Ni-L networks in 2 are tied together by sharing the Ni(II) centers with 1D Ni(II)-dpp chains to yield a 3-fold interpenetrated 3D skeleton, and the Schläfli symbol is (66)2(64⋅82). The pbmb adopting an asymmetrical trans-conformation in 3 links a Ni1 atom as well as a symmetry-related Ni1B (1 - x, 2 - y, 1 - z) atom, affording a [Ni(pbmb)]2 unit following a 16-membered metalloring. The Ni(II) ions of two adjoining 1D Ni(II)/L4- chains were connected together by the trans-conformational pbmb supplying a 2D sheet with a point symbol of (4⋅62)(42⋅62⋅82). For 4, Ni1(II) and Ni2(II) atoms are alternately bridged by the two classes of bmp (bmp-I and bmp-II) to lead to 36-membered macrocyclic rings, which combine with 1D Ni-L parallelogram channels to result in a 3D network with a vertex symbol of (4⋅64⋅8)2(42⋅62⋅82). For 5, the three types of pbib (pbib-I, pbib-II, and pbib-III) behave as a bidentate mode to joint two contiguous Ni(II) ions alternately to afford a 2D net. The Ni/pbib 2D layers are connected by a Ni/L4- 1D chain, inducing a 3D architecture with a point symbol of (4⋅69)(42⋅66⋅82). In 6, there are also three kinds of independent pbib (pbib-I, pbib-II, and pbib-III). The two adjoining Ni2(II) ions are bridged by pbib-I and pbib-III to produce a 1D meso-helix chain. At the same time, the pbib-II links the Ni1(II) ions crossing in the middle of 1D channels that are included in the Ni-L 2D layer. The combination of the 1D meso-helix chains Ni2(II)-(pbib-I)-(pbib-III) and the Ni(II)-L4- 2D nets constructs a complicated 3D framework with the Schläfli symbol of (45⋅5)(47⋅53⋅611). In 7, a trans-conformational beb ligand coordinates with Ni1(II) atoms into a 1D chain. The combination of the 1D Ni(II)/beb chain and 1D Ni(II)/L4- chain leads to a 2D bilayer net.

elements.content: To assess the stability of the architectures 1–7, thermogravimetric analyses were executed in the temperature range of 30–800 °C under an air atmosphere (Figure S9) (Supporting Information). For 1, the mass loss of 9.70% happening between 39 and 137 °C could be associated with the release of one coordinated water molecule and two guest water molecules (calcd 10.42%). The weight loss from 312 to 484 °C corresponds to the losses of bpa and L4–, leading to the NiO residue of 16.49% (calcd, 14.41%). The TG curve of 2 exhibits the mass loss of 6.40% from 38 to 144 °C, which is probably because of the release of four guest water molecules (calcd 6.88%). The weight loss occurring between 374 and 446 °C could be assigned to the decomposition of the organic ligands and one coordinated water, accompanying with the NiO residue of 16.25% (calcd, 14.27%). Complex 3 lost the weight of 5.9% ranging from 119 to 218 °C, which can be attributed to the departure of one coordinated water molecule (calc. 5.8%). The removal of organic components took place at 326 °C, finally, giving a NiO residue of 12.78% (calcd, 12.04%) at 515 °C. Complex 4 presents that the weight loss of 8.99% from 36 to 163 °C is interrelated to the loss of seven lattice water molecules (calcd, 9.21%). The entire skeleton of 4 starts to decompose from 346 to 492 °C, which is parallel to the decomposition of one coordinated water and bmp as well as L4–, and the NiO residue of 11.01% (calcd, 10.91%) is observed. The TGA curve of 5 displays the weight loss process of 5.49% from 74 to 137 °C, which corresponds to the decomposition of two isolated water molecules (calcd, 5.35%). The second step weight loss occurs in the range of 374–506 °C, corresponding to the decomposition of pbib and L4–. A residue of NiO (obsd, 12.10%, calcd, 11.09%) is discovered. For 6, the TGA manifests a weight loss of 5.83% from 39 to 158 °C that involved the release of three lattice water molecules (calcd, 5.56%); afterward, a plateau region is sighted. Eventually, the overall skeleton of 6 gets down to decompose from 363 °C, and the NiO residue of 16.81% (calcd, 15.38%) is observed at 491 °C. The TG curve of 7 reveals the mass loss of 2.30% ranging from 172 to 222 °C, which potentially ascribes to the departure of one coordinated water molecule (calc. 2.60%). The skeleton of 7 began to disassemble at 332 °C; then the NiO residue of 10.87% (calcd, 10.79%) is detected at 571 °C.

elements.content: For the magnetism of these samples, we mainly study the magnetic coupling interactions between metal ions. The structure of 6 includes the binuclear [Ni2(CO2)3] SBU, and the intermetallic distance of Ni1···Ni2 is about 3.440 Å within the bimetallic subunit. Judging from this, the magnetic coupling interactions between metal ions are strong in 6. Therefore, we only investigate the magnetic susceptibility of powdered sample 6 in the range of 2–300 K under a 1 kOe applied magnetic field and discuss the magnetic coupling interactions between Ni­(II) ions. Its magnetic behaviors are demonstrated in Figure S10. At 300 K, the χ M T values of 6 are 2.57 cm3 K mol–1, which is somewhat larger than the spin-only value (2.00 cm3 K mol–1, g = 2.0 and S = 1) anticipated for high-spin [Ni­(II)]2 ions. This disparity might be induced by the spin–orbit coupling characteristic of nickel­(II) complexes with an 3A2g ground state leading to an increasing g factor. As the temperature descends, the value of χ M T decreases sequentially to 0.64 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K, manifesting regnant antiferromagnetic interactions between the Ni­(II) ions linked by carboxylate bridges within the dinuclear cluster. The plot of χ M –1 versus T for 6 adheres to the Curie–Weiss law of 1/χ M = (T – θ)/C in the temperature range of 2–300 K, with the Curie constant C = 2.59 cm3 K mol–1 and the Weiss constant θ = −2.51 K.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties Measurements

For the magnetism of these samples, we mainly study the magnetic coupling interactions between metal ions. The structure of 6 includes the binuclear [Ni2(CO2)3] SBU, and the intermetallic distance of Ni1⋅⋅⋅Ni2 is about 3.440 Å within the bimetallic subunit. Judging from this, the magnetic coupling interactions between metal ions are strong in 6. Therefore, we only investigate the magnetic susceptibility of powdered sample 6 in the range of 2-300 K under a 1 kOe applied magnetic field and discuss the magnetic coupling interactions between Ni(II) ions. Its magnetic behaviors are demonstrated in Figure S10. At 300 K, the χ M  T values of 6 are 2.57 cm3 K mol-1, which is somewhat larger than the spin-only value (2.00 cm3 K mol-1, g = 2.0 and S = 1) anticipated for high-spin [Ni(II)]2 ions. This disparity might be induced by the spin-orbit coupling characteristic of nickel(II) complexes with an 3A2g ground state leading to an increasing g factor. As the temperature descends, the value of χ M  T decreases sequentially to 0.64 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K, manifesting regnant antiferromagnetic interactions between the Ni(II) ions linked by carboxylate bridges within the dinuclear cluster. The plot of χ M  -1 versus T for 6 adheres to the Curie-Weiss law of 1/χ M  = (T - θ)/C in the temperature range of 2-300 K, with the Curie constant C = 2.59 cm3 K mol-1 and the Weiss constant θ = -2.51 K.

elements.content: Carefully looking into the structure of 6, the magnetic exchange pathways between dimeric Ni­(II) ions for 6 have been found, which comprises two syn–anti carboxyl bridges (Ni–OCO–Ni) and one μ2-Ocarboxyl bridge with the exchange angle Ni–Ocarboxyl–Ni of 111.129° between Ni1 and Ni2. To quantitatively evaluate the magnetic interactions in 6, the magnetic data were analyzed by way of the presentation for a dinuclear Ni­(II) system (S1 = S2 = 1) evolved from the isotropic spin Hamiltonian H = −2J∑S1S2 with the effect of synergy of zero-field splitting not considered and the interaction between adjacent dinuclear units taken into account. χ d = 2 N g 2 β 2 k T [ exp ( 2 J / k T ) + 5 exp ( 6 J / k T ) 1 + 3 exp ( 2 J / k T ) + 5 exp ( 6 J / k T ) ] χ M = χ d 1 − χ d ( 2 z J ′ / N g 2 β 2 )

elements.content: The prime fitting parameters are J = −1.02 cm–1, zJ′ = −0.01 cm–1, g = 2.27, and R = 2.31 × 10–4. These results sustain the manipulation of a weak intradimer antiferromagnetic interaction as well as a very weak interdimer interaction in 6.
elements.clean_text: The prime fitting parameters are J = -1.02 cm-1, zJ' = -0.01 cm-1, g = 2.27, and R = 2.31 × 10-4. These results sustain the manipulation of a weak intradimer antiferromagnetic interaction as well as a very weak interdimer interaction in 6.

elements.content: Several coordination architectures have been certified to be promising semiconductors in the former literature. Illuminated by these files, we inspected the conductivity potentials of complexes 1–7. As depicted in , the diffuse-reflectance UV–vis spectrum of the H4L displays two doughty absorption bands (λmax = 257 nm, 4.82 eV; λmax = 328 nm, 3.78 eV) in the range of 200–400 nm, which are assigned to the typical π → π* transitions. Besides, the UV–vis absorption spectra of these N-donor coligands manifest stronger absorption bands and the maxima is less than 300 nm (4.13 eV), such as 205, 245, and 283 nm for bpa, 202 and 245 nm for dpp, 208 and 255 nm for pbmb, 205 and 251 nm for bmp, 240 and 257 nm for pbib, and 211 and 294 nm for beb in the scale of 200–400 nm. In the light of the relevant literatures, the absorption bands of all the free N-donor ligands are attributable to the π → π* transitions of the aromatic rings, severally. As pictured , 1–7 show the analogous absorption bands with maxima more than 600 nm (2.06 eV), which can be principally ascribed to the d–d transition of the Ni­(II) ion. According to method in the literatures, we obtain the plot of Kubelka–Munk function F versus energy E and assess the band gaps (E g) of 1–7 (Figure S11). The E g values are 1.23 eV for 1, 1.13 eV for 2, 1.09 eV for 3, 1.17 eV for 4, 1.20 eV for 5, 1.25 eV for 6, and 1.19 eV for 7, singly. The smaller E g values are in favor of the electron transition, which may be beneficial to catalysis.
elements.clean_text:
Photophysical Properties and Optical Band Gaps

Several coordination architectures have been certified to be promising semiconductors in the former literature. Illuminated by these files, we inspected the conductivity potentials of complexes 1-7. As depicted in , the diffuse-reflectance UV-vis spectrum of the H4L displays two doughty absorption bands (λmax = 257 nm, 4.82 eV; λmax = 328 nm, 3.78 eV) in the range of 200-400 nm, which are assigned to the typical π → π* transitions. Besides, the UV-vis absorption spectra of these N-donor coligands manifest stronger absorption bands and the maxima is less than 300 nm (4.13 eV), such as 205, 245, and 283 nm for bpa, 202 and 245 nm for dpp, 208 and 255 nm for pbmb, 205 and 251 nm for bmp, 240 and 257 nm for pbib, and 211 and 294 nm for beb in the scale of 200-400 nm. In the light of the relevant literatures, the absorption bands of all the free N-donor ligands are attributable to the π → π* transitions of the aromatic rings, severally. As pictured , 1-7 show the analogous absorption bands with maxima more than 600 nm (2.06 eV), which can be principally ascribed to the d-d transition of the Ni(II) ion. According to method in the literatures, we obtain the plot of Kubelka-Munk function F versus energy E and assess the band gaps (E g) of 1-7 (Figure S11). The E g values are 1.23 eV for 1, 1.13 eV for 2, 1.09 eV for 3, 1.17 eV for 4, 1.20 eV for 5, 1.25 eV for 6, and 1.19 eV for 7, singly. The smaller E g values are in favor of the electron transition, which may be beneficial to catalysis.

elements.content: The homocoupling reactions of aryl halides represent vigoroso synthetic methods for symmetrical biaryls and play momentous roles on fine chemical and pharmaceutical industries. To date, the complexes as heterogeneous catalysts have almost not been reported in the Ullmann reaction. Herein, we study the complexes-catalyzed homocoupling of iodobenzene under the condition of the presence of metallic magnesium. Compared with orthodox catalysts for this reaction, the introduction of the metal-complexes catalysts will bring some advantages, such as the lower amount of catalyst, mild reaction conditions, nonpoisonous, and environmental friendliness. 1 and 2 are both 3-fold interpenetrated networks, which are of no advantage to this reaction, and the crystal yield of 4 is a little low. Accordingly, complexes 1, 2, and 4 will not be candidates for suitable catalysts.
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic Capacity

The homocoupling reactions of aryl halides represent vigoroso synthetic methods for symmetrical biaryls and play momentous roles on fine chemical and pharmaceutical industries. To date, the complexes as heterogeneous catalysts have almost not been reported in the Ullmann reaction. Herein, we study the complexes-catalyzed homocoupling of iodobenzene under the condition of the presence of metallic magnesium. Compared with orthodox catalysts for this reaction, the introduction of the metal-complexes catalysts will bring some advantages, such as the lower amount of catalyst, mild reaction conditions, nonpoisonous, and environmental friendliness. 1 and 2 are both 3-fold interpenetrated networks, which are of no advantage to this reaction, and the crystal yield of 4 is a little low. Accordingly, complexes 1, 2, and 4 will not be candidates for suitable catalysts.

elements.content: To research the catalytic activity of complexes, we need to verify their stable existence in common solvents. Hence, the analyses of solvent resistance property are carried out in the first place. The chemical resistance of complexes 3, 5, 6, and 7 was interrogated via suspending these samples in boiling N,N′-dimethylformamide, acetonitrile, tetrahydrofuran, ethanol, methanol, and water for about 48 h by following representative industrial chemical processes. In the interval, the crystal samples were observed under a microscope in cycles. For 3, it could keep its original shape not only in the water, but also in acetonitrile. 5 is superior to 3 for it could preserve its original shape in N,N′-dimethylformamide, acetonitrile, and water, while 6 could save its original shape in ethanol, acetonitrile, and water. What’s particularly attractive is that 7 conveyes preeminent chemical resistance to those solvents mentioned above except for boiling methanol. X-ray diffraction indicated that their unit-cell parameters well-nigh did not change (Table S3). Perceptibly, their primal frameworks were integrated and unbroken. It is strange that this four complexes all could not store in boiling methanol. The outstanding chemical resistance of 7 in refluxing water as well as ecumenical organic solvents is passably assigned to the existence of a two-dimensional bilayer, which could be in favor of the stability of the skeletons.

What's particularly attractive is that 7 conveyes preeminent chemical resistance to those solvents mentioned above except for boiling methanol. The outstanding chemical resistance of 7 in refluxing water as well as ecumenical organic solvents is passably assigned to the existence of a two-dimensional bilayer, which could be in favor of the stability of the skeletons.

elements.content: Finally, we survey the catalytic activity of the complexes 3, 5, 6, and 7 in detail and find that they are effective catalysts for the homocoupling of iodobenzene. The catalytic results of 3, 5, 6, and 7 are listed in . They give a conversion of 49, 51, 44, and 48% for biphenyl compounds, severally. This situation shows that 3, 5, 6, and 7 have catalytic activities for the synthesis of the symmetric biphenyl compounds. In 3, although the Ni­(II) ions are six-coordinated, the associated water molecule, which is a fine leaving group, is likely to depart during the catalytic process. As a result, the remaining unsaturated nickel sites (five-coordinated) are exposed to the reaction substrate, which will be beneficial to this reaction. Besides, the atoms in the L4– anion are nearly in the same plane for 3. This causes the 2D structure of 3 to possess numerous large open channels (dimensions of 16.393 × 11.571 Å and 15.198 × 11.582 Å). The big open channels can promote the transport of organic substrates and products (biphenyl), taking advantage of the touch of the substrates and the catalytic active sites. Unfortunately, the Ni­(II) ions are both six-coordinated and the coordinated waters are absent in 5 and 6. The good news is that the existence of the 1D channel will be conducive to the transmission of the reaction substrates in 5 (dimensions of 9.999 × 9.275 Å) and 6 (dimensions of 21.377 × 13.840 Å), further facilitating the catalytic reaction. As for 7, the six-coordinated Ni­(II) ion contains one associated water molecule, which will be a boon for the well-off occurrence of the catalytic reaction. On the basis of these discussions, we speculate that the porosity, which is a favorable factor for the catalytic reaction, may improve the catalyst activity. Because our catalytic reaction is heterogeneous catalysis, the catalysts having a large enough surface area are necessary. Moreover, to attest to the stability of samples after catalytic reaction, we take 3 for example. The superb match between the PXRD of the 3 retrieved from the catalytic reaction as well as that of the initial solid of 3 attests to that 3 is strong in the catalytic condition (Figure S12). The SEM images of catalysts after catalytic reaction have also been unfolded in Figure S13. These samples exhibit a similar morphology consisting of irregular particles with a wide particle size distribution, which is possibly the reasons leading to alike catalytic effect. A conceivable mechanism is proposed in Scheme S3. First, the Grignard reagent, which is produced by iodobenzene and magnesium, is activated by the catalyst (3, 5, 6, or 7) to provide I. Then, this species I reacted with iodobenzene to produce a diaryl-substituted nickel complex intermediate II. Reductive elimination of the homocoupling product revitalized the catalytically active species catalyst (3, 5, 6, or 7).

In brief, seven Ni­(II)/L4–/N-donor coligands coordination polymers with alluring frameworks have been triumphantly built under hydrothermal/solvothermal conditions. This work implies that the use of mixed ligands is a rational and feasible tactic to adjust and control the development of high-dimensionality skeletons. The structural diversities of polymers 1–7 indicate that the conformation of the H4L ligand and additional N-donors play critical roles in the assembly of the final framework. Magnetic studies of 6 indicate that it may be a potential magnetic material. Furthermore, in the complexes-catalyzed homocoupling reaction of iodobenzene, 3, 5, 6, and 7 have been confirmed to be valid catalysts for the preparation of the biphenyl. Succedent studies will concentrate on the catalytic performance of diversiform complexes fabricated by the flexible tetracarboxylic acid ligands and more N-donor ligands as well as other metal ions.

Conclusions

In brief, seven Ni(II)/L4-/N-donor coligands coordination polymers with alluring frameworks have been triumphantly built under hydrothermal/solvothermal conditions. This work implies that the use of mixed ligands is a rational and feasible tactic to adjust and control the development of high-dimensionality skeletons. Magnetic studies of 6 indicate that it may be a potential magnetic material. Furthermore, in the complexes-catalyzed homocoupling reaction of iodobenzene, 3, 5, 6, and 7 have been confirmed to be valid catalysts for the preparation of the biphenyl. Succedent studies will concentrate on the catalytic performance of diversiform complexes fabricated by the flexible tetracarboxylic acid ligands and more N-donor ligands as well as other metal ions.

General Procedure of the Preparation of the Biaryl Compounds with Catalysts <bold>1</bold>–<bold>7</bold>

Iodobenzene (0.5 mmol), catalyst (0.05 mmol, complexes 1–7), and magnesium ribbon (0.6 mmol) were mixed together and refluxed in anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (2 mL) under dry air. After 6 h, the cool reacting solution was filtrated and the dilute hydrochloric acid (0.5 N, 10 mL) was added into the filtrate. The mixture was then extracted with acetic ether, and the combined organic layers were washed with water and then dried by anhydrous sodium sulfate, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. The raw product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel with hexane. Column chromatography was implemented with 200–300 mesh silica gel. 1H NMR spectra were taken on a 400 MHz instrument (see the Supporting Information).

cln_elements.content:
To assess the stability of the architectures 1–7, thermogravimetric analyses were executed in the temperature range of 30–800 °C under an air atmosphere (Figure S9) (Supporting Information). For 1, the mass loss of 9.70% happening between 39 and 137 °C could be associated with the release of one coordinated water molecule and two guest water molecules (calcd 10.42%). The weight loss from 312 to 484 °C corresponds to the losses of bpa and L4–, leading to the NiO residue of 16.49% (calcd, 14.41%). The TG curve of 2 exhibits the mass loss of 6.40% from 38 to 144 °C, which is probably because of the release of four guest water molecules (calcd 6.88%). The weight loss occurring between 374 and 446 °C could be assigned to the decomposition of the organic ligands and one coordinated water, accompanying with the NiO residue of 16.25% (calcd, 14.27%). Complex 3 lost the weight of 5.9% ranging from 119 to 218 °C, which can be attributed to the departure of one coordinated water molecule (calc. 5.8%). The removal of organic components took place at 326 °C, finally, giving a NiO residue of 12.78% (calcd, 12.04%) at 515 °C. Complex 4 presents that the weight loss of 8.99% from 36 to 163 °C is interrelated to the loss of seven lattice water molecules (calcd, 9.21%). The entire skeleton of 4 starts to decompose from 346 to 492 °C, which is parallel to the decomposition of one coordinated water and bmp as well as L4–, and the NiO residue of 11.01% (calcd, 10.91%) is observed. The TGA curve of 5 displays the weight loss process of 5.49% from 74 to 137 °C, which corresponds to the decomposition of two isolated water molecules (calcd, 5.35%). The second step weight loss occurs in the range of 374–506 °C, corresponding to the decomposition of pbib and L4–. A residue of NiO (obsd, 12.10%, calcd, 11.09%) is discovered. For 6, the TGA manifests a weight loss of 5.83% from 39 to 158 °C that involved the release of three lattice water molecules (calcd, 5.56%); afterward, a plateau region is sighted. Eventually, the overall skeleton of 6 gets down to decompose from 363 °C, and the NiO residue of 16.81% (calcd, 15.38%) is observed at 491 °C. The TG curve of 7 reveals the mass loss of 2.30% ranging from 172 to 222 °C, which potentially ascribes to the departure of one coordinated water molecule (calc. 2.60%). The skeleton of 7 began to disassemble at 332 °C; then the NiO residue of 10.87% (calcd, 10.79%) is detected at 571 °C.

Magnetic Properties Measurements

For the magnetism of these samples, we mainly study the magnetic coupling interactions between metal ions. The structure of 6 includes the binuclear [Ni2(CO2)3] SBU, and the intermetallic distance of Ni1···Ni2 is about 3.440 Å within the bimetallic subunit. Judging from this, the magnetic coupling interactions between metal ions are strong in 6. Therefore, we only investigate the magnetic susceptibility of powdered sample 6 in the range of 2–300 K under a 1 kOe applied magnetic field and discuss the magnetic coupling interactions between Ni­(II) ions. Its magnetic behaviors are demonstrated in Figure S10. At 300 K, the χ M T values of 6 are 2.57 cm3 K mol–1, which is somewhat larger than the spin-only value (2.00 cm3 K mol–1, g = 2.0 and S = 1) anticipated for high-spin [Ni­(II)]2 ions. This disparity might be induced by the spin–orbit coupling characteristic of nickel­(II) complexes with an 3A2g ground state leading to an increasing g factor. As the temperature descends, the value of χ M T decreases sequentially to 0.64 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K, manifesting regnant antiferromagnetic interactions between the Ni­(II) ions linked by carboxylate bridges within the dinuclear cluster. The plot of χ M –1 versus T for 6 adheres to the Curie–Weiss law of 1/χ M = (T – θ)/C in the temperature range of 2–300 K, with the Curie constant C = 2.59 cm3 K mol–1 and the Weiss constant θ = −2.51 K.

Photophysical Properties and Optical Band Gaps

Several coordination architectures have been certified to be promising semiconductors in the former literature. Illuminated by these files, we inspected the conductivity potentials of complexes 1–7. As depicted in , the diffuse-reflectance UV–vis spectrum of the H4L displays two doughty absorption bands (λmax = 257 nm, 4.82 eV; λmax = 328 nm, 3.78 eV) in the range of 200–400 nm, which are assigned to the typical π → π* transitions. Besides, the UV–vis absorption spectra of these N-donor coligands manifest stronger absorption bands and the maxima is less than 300 nm (4.13 eV), such as 205, 245, and 283 nm for bpa, 202 and 245 nm for dpp, 208 and 255 nm for pbmb, 205 and 251 nm for bmp, 240 and 257 nm for pbib, and 211 and 294 nm for beb in the scale of 200–400 nm. In the light of the relevant literatures, the absorption bands of all the free N-donor ligands are attributable to the π → π* transitions of the aromatic rings, severally. As pictured , 1–7 show the analogous absorption bands with maxima more than 600 nm (2.06 eV), which can be principally ascribed to the d–d transition of the Ni­(II) ion. According to method in the literatures, we obtain the plot of Kubelka–Munk function F versus energy E and assess the band gaps (E g) of 1–7 (Figure S11). The E g values are 1.23 eV for 1, 1.13 eV for 2, 1.09 eV for 3, 1.17 eV for 4, 1.20 eV for 5, 1.25 eV for 6, and 1.19 eV for 7, singly. The smaller E g values are in favor of the electron transition, which may be beneficial to catalysis.

Magnetic Properties Measurements

For the magnetism of these samples, we mainly study the magnetic coupling interactions between metal ions. The structure of 6 includes the binuclear [Ni2(CO2)3] SBU, and the intermetallic distance of Ni1⋅⋅⋅Ni2 is about 3.440 Å within the bimetallic subunit. Judging from this, the magnetic coupling interactions between metal ions are strong in 6. Therefore, we only investigate the magnetic susceptibility of powdered sample 6 in the range of 2-300 K under a 1 kOe applied magnetic field and discuss the magnetic coupling interactions between Ni(II) ions. Its magnetic behaviors are demonstrated in Figure S10. At 300 K, the χ M  T values of 6 are 2.57 cm3 K mol-1, which is somewhat larger than the spin-only value (2.00 cm3 K mol-1, g = 2.0 and S = 1) anticipated for high-spin [Ni(II)]2 ions. This disparity might be induced by the spin-orbit coupling characteristic of nickel(II) complexes with an 3A2g ground state leading to an increasing g factor. As the temperature descends, the value of χ M  T decreases sequentially to 0.64 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K, manifesting regnant antiferromagnetic interactions between the Ni(II) ions linked by carboxylate bridges within the dinuclear cluster. The plot of χ M  -1 versus T for 6 adheres to the Curie-Weiss law of 1/χ M  = (T - θ)/C in the temperature range of 2-300 K, with the Curie constant C = 2.59 cm3 K mol-1 and the Weiss constant θ = -2.51 K.

Photophysical Properties and Optical Band Gaps

Several coordination architectures have been certified to be promising semiconductors in the former literature. Illuminated by these files, we inspected the conductivity potentials of complexes 1-7. As depicted in , the diffuse-reflectance UV-vis spectrum of the H4L displays two doughty absorption bands (λmax = 257 nm, 4.82 eV; λmax = 328 nm, 3.78 eV) in the range of 200-400 nm, which are assigned to the typical π → π* transitions. Besides, the UV-vis absorption spectra of these N-donor coligands manifest stronger absorption bands and the maxima is less than 300 nm (4.13 eV), such as 205, 245, and 283 nm for bpa, 202 and 245 nm for dpp, 208 and 255 nm for pbmb, 205 and 251 nm for bmp, 240 and 257 nm for pbib, and 211 and 294 nm for beb in the scale of 200-400 nm. In the light of the relevant literatures, the absorption bands of all the free N-donor ligands are attributable to the π → π* transitions of the aromatic rings, severally. As pictured , 1-7 show the analogous absorption bands with maxima more than 600 nm (2.06 eV), which can be principally ascribed to the d-d transition of the Ni(II) ion. According to method in the literatures, we obtain the plot of Kubelka-Munk function F versus energy E and assess the band gaps (E g) of 1-7 (Figure S11). The E g values are 1.23 eV for 1, 1.13 eV for 2, 1.09 eV for 3, 1.17 eV for 4, 1.20 eV for 5, 1.25 eV for 6, and 1.19 eV for 7, singly. The smaller E g values are in favor of the electron transition, which may be beneficial to catalysis.
